instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v after water damage
threads.message:
i have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v at the charger 0.04 amps.

I am not getting <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at the source of <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>. <SIGNAL>UPC_XA_GATE2</SIGNAL> shows 6.5v, but <SIGNAL>UPC_XA_GATE1</SIGNAL> is 7v.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.3 v

i replaced the CD321500z, still the same problem.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_SX</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> 1.1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v after water damage
threads.message:
Do you get same voltages on XV lines?
Where was the water spill?

Do you get all SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages?
Which is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v after water damage
threads.message:
"Do you get the same voltages on XV lines? " where is this net ? cant find it


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
SLPS2R  1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.8V

the water was split on the trackpad

sometime after plugging and unpluging the usb cable so many times, i get 20v 0 amps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5v after water damage
threads.message:
I meant XA, sorry for misstyping.

Looks like you still have corrosion problems.
